Sublime Derwent comeback fails to secure title

10/03/2013

An inspired comeback by Derwent in the second half against Alcuin secured the win they needed to keep their hopes of winning the Spring league alive, despite trailing 2-1 at half-time

Image by

By undefined undefined

DERWENT 4-2 ALCUIN
Images: Philippa Grafton An inspired comeback by Derwent in the second half against Alcuin secured the win they needed to keep their hopes of winning the Spring league alive, despite trailing 2-1 at half-time. If results had gone Derwent's way in the match between the joint league leaders Wentworth and Vanbrugh on the 3G, a win for Derwent and a draw at the Sports Village would have put them on top. Meanwhile, Alcuin welcomed back some old faces from yonder years through the ex-skipper and pacey winger Miles McDermott and powerhouse striker Udy Onwudike. Derwent started the game with ten men as they awaited the arrival of their goalscoring talisman Jamie Trant, and Alcuin's advantage was telling in the earliest moments of the game when they took the lead through Greg Fearn - he was given too much space on the edge of the box as he pinged the ball off the left-hand post and into the goal. With the wind and the peculiar gradient on 22 Acres working in their favour, Alcuin continued to dominate the early chances as Kimber was denied by a smart save from Ruari Franklin and Onwudike had a goal pinched off him on the line by Ryan Gwinnett. At the other end of the pitch, Derwent were struggling to get their usual fast, attacking moves into action; many of their rare runs into the Alcuin half often lacked a final pass. Their closest chance came when Gwinnett worked the ball into the box before laying the ball to a supporting David Kirk on the right, whos fizzing shot to Nock across the six-yard box could only be knocked into the arms of David Marshall. Alcuin doubled their lead deservedly on 35 minutes; fantastic pressure by Onwudike on stand-in centre-back Ollie Harrison won Alcuin a corner. Fearn's inswinger found the head of Jacob Burge with ease when he gave his marker the slip. Derwent had slowly been building momentum as the half went on and they found a goal shortly before half-time as they began to press higher up the pitch. Left-back Harry Lambert low shot forced a strong save from Alcuin keeper Marshall, but Mark Askham reacted quicker that the Alcuin defence as he poached himself a goal off the rebound. The second half started relatively slower to the first and Alcuin continued to dominate the early chances: McDermott and Fernando came close. After the hour mark, however, Derwent finally found their equaliser. An exquisite one-two move between Alex D'Albertanson and Trant allowed the latter to beat Alcuin right-back Houlgate and fire off a shot. It ricocheted fiercly off the near post and fell nicely for D'Albertanson to shoot again but Marshall saved well with his feet. The rebound once more fell to D'Albertanson and this time he made no error in placing the ball into the far bottom corner. With the wind in their sails (quite literally), a boost in confidence and a change in formation to 4-3-3 meant Derwent were starting to dominate possession for the first time in the game. D'Albertanson showed his form once more as he fed Askham at the far post, but a sprawling Marshall pulled out a fine block. 15 minutes before the final whistle, Derwent finally took the lead. The referee questionably called a foul throw against Alcuin and Lambert's following throw for Derwent was deflected into the chest of Trant. He was able to pick out the overlapping run of Askham, who slotted the ball coolly into the goal via the near post. Derwent's fourth also came under slightly controversial circumstances; Trant found himself with the ball in centre from a Derwent deflection, despite coming from an offside position. Regardless, the referee allowed play to go on as Trant rounded the keeper and put the game to bed. In search of a hat-trick, Askham moved upfront for the final moments of the match. In the dying moments, Trant gave him the ball on a plate at the far post, but he somehow managed to scuff his shot wide. Alcuin almost found a consolation goal just before full time as they tested Franklin from range but he couldn't hold it. Brough slid to knock the ball out of Franlin's reach towards goal but Derwent skipper Kirk miraculously slid in to clear it off the line. The game finished with Askham missing another golden chance to claim his hat-trick, but the defender managed to miss once more as they rest of his team simultaneously dropped to the floor in synchronised disbelief. Alcuin skipper Chris Boyd told Nouse: "We were great in the first half and in the second half we had a similar amount of chances but theirs cut more. We changed the formation [this term] and I think we going to playing with it next term, I think it's made us play a lot better, so hopefully we can carry that on to the College Cup." David Kirk, Derwent captain, was now in a much finer mood that the one he started the morning with: "To be honest, the whole experience turned out to be one of the most troubled ones of my life - entirely forgettable, but it was a good game. The first-rate Spartan [Askham] popped up with a couple of goals, [on missing out on a hat-trick] he got a bit of a nose bleed at the crucial moment." Man of the match: Alex D'Albertanson Alcuin: Marshall, Houlgate, Billimore, Boyd (C), Dodgson, Burge (Simpson), Kimber (Armstrong), Fearn, McDermott, Fernando, Onwudike (Brough). Derwent: Franklin, Lambert, Moro, Harrison, Askham, Gwinnett, D'Albertanson, Earle, Kirk (C), Nock, Trant.
